sen.j: 大学別曹（だいがくべっそう）は大学寮の付属機関である。
sen.e: Daigakubesso were affiliated facilities under Daigakuryo (the government facility established in the eighth century to educate students-to-be-bureaucrats).
Daigakubesso were facilities affiliated to the Daigakuryo (the government facility established in the eighth century to educate students who were to become bureaucrats).
Daigaku-besso were facilities affiliated to the Daigaku-ryo (the government facility established in the eighth century to educate students who were to become bureaucrats).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: ただし、実際の運営は設置した氏族に属し、大学寮の統制下にはなかった。
sen.e: However, they were operated by their founder families, and not controlled by Daigakuryo.
However, they were operated by their founder families, and not controlled by Daigakuryo.
However, they were operated by their founder families, and not controlled by Daigaku-ryo.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 大学寮の学生は原則として寮内にあった寄宿舎である直曹（じきそう）に寄宿していた（なお、学令に学生の直曹寄宿の義務規定はないものの、学生生活に関する規定が存在しており、学生生活を大学寮が管理する方針が存在したと考えられており、後述の貞観式の規定に至る）。
sen.e: Students of Daigakuryo lived in a dormitory called 'Jikiso' inside Daigakuryo as a general rule (although living in Jikiso was not imperative, the fact that there was a code of living for the students of Daigakuryo implies it had a policy to control students' lives, which would be connected to Jogan-shiki that will be mentioned later).

Students of the Daigakuryo lived in a dormitory called 'Jikiso' inside the Daigakuryo as a general rule (although living in Jikiso was not imperative, the fact that there was a code of living for the students of the Daigakuryo implies it had a policy to control students' lives, which would be connected to the Jogan-shiki that will be mentioned later).

Students of the Daigaku-ryo lived in a dormitory called 'Jikiso' inside the Daigaku-ryo as a general rule (although living in Jikiso was not imperative, the fact that there was a code of living for the students of the Daigaku-ryo implies it had a policy to control student life, which would be connected to the Jogan-shiki Code that will be mentioned later).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: しかし平安時代になって、文章博士として代々世襲を続けた菅原氏が直曹である文章院を創建した（既存のものを拡充したとする見方もある）。
sen.e: In the Heian period, the Sugawara clan who succeeded Monjo-hakase (a professor at Daigakuryo) for generations established Monjoin as Jikiso (it is also said to have been an expanded old one).

In the Heian period, the Sugawara clan who succeeded to the position of Monjo-hakase (professor at the Daigakuryo) for many generations established the Monjoin as the Jikiso (it is also said to have been an expanded old one).

In the Heian period, the Sugawara clan who succeeded to the position of Monjo-hakase (professor at the Daigaku-ryo) for many generations established the Monjoin as the Jikiso (it is also said to have been an expanded old one).

sen.j: その後、文章博士の地位が向上し、なおかつ菅原氏の文章博士の世襲が進むと、文章院及びそこに寄宿する学生に対する菅原氏の支配が強まることとなった。
sen.e: Later, as Monjo-hakase rose in position, and the Sugawara clan continued ever to succeed Monjo-hakase, the Sugawara clan's dominance over Monjoin and its students became even more stronger.

Later, as the position of the Monjo-hakase rose in status, and the Sugawara clan continued to succeed to the role, the Sugawara clan's dominance over the Monjoin and its students became even more stronger.

sen.j: これに反発した有力氏族が相次いで寮の外に一族用の寄宿舎を建設した。
sen.e: Reacting against this situation, other powerful clans built their own dormitories outside Daigakuryo one after another.
Reacting against this situation, other powerful clans built their own dormitories outside the Daigakuryo one after the other.
Reacting against this situation, other powerful clans built their own dormitories outside the Daigaku-ryo one after the other.

sen.j: このため、大学（寮）直曹である文章院に対して大学別曹と呼んだ。
sen.e: These dormitories were called 'Daigakubesso' in distinction to Monjoin which was a Jikiso of Daigakuryo.
These dormitories were called 'Daigakubesso' to distinguish them from the Monjoin which was a Jikiso of the Daigakuryo.
These dormitories were called Daigaku-besso to distinguish them from the Monjoin which was a Jikiso of the Daigaku-ryo.

sen.j: 当初、朝廷はこれを学生を公平に扱う上で不都合と考えて、貞観式（大学寮）において「およそ寮家に住せざるものは貢挙するを得ざれ」の一文を設けている。
sen.e: At first, the Imperial court thought this situation was unfair to the students, so it put a sentence 'anyone who do not live in the dormitory of Daigakuryo cannot be recommended for an officer' in Jogan-shiki (a book of laws and regulations compiled in the Jogan era).

At first, the Imperial court thought this situation was unfair to the students, so it inserted the statement that 'no student who lives outside the dormitory of the Daigakuryo can be recommended to be an officer' into the Jogan-shiki (a book of laws and regulations compiled in the Jogan Era).
sen.cmt: Grammar, made to sound more natural.

sen.j: これに対して藤原良房ら藤原氏が巻き返しを図った結果、藤原氏の勧学院は大学別曹として朝廷の認可を受けたと考えられている。
sen.e: Kangakuin of the Fujiwara clan is thought to have gained the Imperial court's approval as a Daigakubesso because FUJIWARA no Yoshifusa and other members of the Fujiwara clan fought back against the setback.

The Kangakuin of the Fujiwara clan is thought to have gained the Imperial court's approval as a Daigakubesso because FUJIWARA no Yoshifusa and other members of the Fujiwara clan fought back against the setback.

The Kangakuin of the Fujiwara clan is thought to have gained the Imperial court's approval as a Daigaku-besso because FUJIWARA no Yoshifusa and other members of the Fujiwara clan fought back against the setback.

sen.j: 大学別曹はあくまで寄宿舎であり、自習場所や書庫などが設置されていたものの、大学寮の学生であること（あるいはその入学準備者）が寄宿の要件であり、試験や講義は全て大学に通って受けることとなっていた。
sen.e: Only the students of Daigakuryo (or students preparing for the entrance) were allowed to live in a Daigakubesso which was a dormitory equipped with a library and a room to study, and the students had to attend Daigakuryo to take classes and examinations.

Only the students of the Daigakuryo (or students preparing for entrance to it) were allowed to live in a Daigakubesso which was a dormitory equipped with a library and a room to study, and the students had to attend the Daigakuryo to take classes and examinations.

Only the students of the Daigaku-ryo (or students preparing for entrance to it) were allowed to live in a Daigaku-besso which was a dormitory equipped with a library and a room to study, and the students had to attend the Daigaku-ryo to take classes and examinations.

sen.j: 後世、大学別曹を「私立学校」とする見解（重野安譯「本邦古来教育ノ大概」など）が出されたが、大学別曹に専門の教員が置かれて講義がなされたという記録はなく、また当時において私立学校に相当するものは、大学寮の教員や著名な学者が教員の自宅で講義を行った一種の「私塾」であったと想定できる（例菅原氏の菅家廊下）ために、この見解は成り立たない。
sen.e: Although later in the Meiji period a remark that claimed Daigakubesso were 'private schools' was published (Yasutsugu SHIGENO, 'Honpo Korai Kyoiku no Taigai' (Overview of the Education in Ancient Japan)), this is not true, because there is no record that Daigakubesso had its teachers to give lectures, and at that time there were kinds of 'shijuku' (private tutoring schools at teachers' homes) that corresponded to private schools, where teachers in Daigakuryo or reputed scholars provided lectures (example: Kankeroka (菅家廊下) of the Sugawara clan).

Although later, in the Meiji Period, the remark that Daigakubesso were 'private schools' was published in Yasutsugu SHIGENO's 'Honpo Korai Kyoiku no Taigai' (Overview of the Education of Ancient Japan), this is not borne out by the facts, because there is no record that Daigakubesso had specialist teachers to give lectures, and at that time there were kinds of 'shijuku' (private tutoring schools at teachers' homes) that corresponded to private schools, where teachers in the Daigakuryo or reputed scholars provided lectures (example: Kankeroka (菅家廊下) of the Sugawara clan).

Although later, in the Meiji period, the remark that Daigaku-besso were 'private schools' was published in Yasutsugu SHIGENO's 'Honpo Korai Kyoiku no Taigai' (Overview of the Education of Ancient Japan), this is not borne out by the facts, because there is no record that Daigaku-besso had specialist teachers to give lectures, and at that time there were kinds of 'shijuku' (private tutoring schools at teachers' homes) that corresponded to private schools, where teachers in the Daigaku-ryo or reputed scholars provided lectures (example: Kanke Roka School of the Sugawara clan).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 大学別曹は公的な寄宿舎ではないため大学寮の支配が及ばず、各氏の氏長者・是定（ぜじょう）の下で管理されたが、のちには荘園や大学寮の任官試験を経ずに官職に就く特権（年挙）が与えられた。
sen.e: Uji no Choja (chief of a clan) or Zejo (an acting head of a clan) of each clan managed its Daigakubesso which was not an official dormitory and not controlled by Daigakuryo, but later their students were given a special privilege (called 'Nenkyo') to take a bureaucratic post without sitting for appointment examinations of Shoen (manors) or Daigakuryo.

The Uji no Choja (clan cheiftain) or the Zejo (acting head of a clan) of each clan managed its Daigakubesso which was neither an official dormitory nor controlled by the Daigakuryo, but later their students were given a special privilege (called 'Nenkyo') to take a bureaucratic post without sitting for appointment examinations for Shoen (manors) or the Daigakuryo.

The uji no choja (the head of the clan) or the Zejo (the title of the chieftain of a clan especially the Tachibana clan) of each clan managed its Daigaku-besso which was neither an official dormitory nor controlled by the Daigaku-ryo, but later their students were given a special privilege (called 'Nenkyo') to take a bureaucratic post without sitting for appointment examinations for Shoen (manors) or the Daigaku-ryo.
sen.cmt: ウェブに合わせ、「是定」を原文、訳文ともに補足、修正しました。

sen.j: 各氏の衰えとともに別曹も荒廃し藤原氏の勧学院以外は形式のみとなった。
sen.e: Over time Daigakubesso deteriorated to be only a form as the power of other clans decreased except for Kangakuin of the Fujiwara clan.
Over time Daigakubesso declined to such an extent that they became only a form as the power of other clans decreased, with the exception of the Kangakuin of the Fujiwara clan.
Over time Daigaku-besso declined to such an extent that they became only a form as the power of other clans decreased, with the exception of the Kangakuin of the Fujiwara clan.

sen.j: ただし､形式のみといっても院政期からは後院である淳和院とともに代々の源氏長者が務める役職として「淳和奨学両院別当」という称号が作られ、のちに武家である足利将軍・徳川将軍の称号の一つとなる。
sen.e: Although most Daigakubesso (including Shogakuin) became only titles, in Inseiki (the period of the cloister government), a title 'Junnain Shogakuin Betto (superintendent)' was created along with Junnain, Goin (a palace of a retired Emperor) of the retired Emperor Junna, as a post of successive Genji Choja (chief of the Minamoto clan), and this title later became one of the titles of samurai families, Ashikaga Shogun and Tokugawa Shogun.

Although most Daigakubesso (including Shogakuin) became merely titles, during Inseiki (the period of the cloister government), a title 'Junnain Shogakuin Betto' (superintendent) was created along with the Junnain, the Goin (palace of the retired Emperor) of the retired Emperor Junna, as a post for successive Genji Choja (chiefs of the Minamoto clan), and this title later became one of the titles of samurai families, such as Ashikaga Shogun and Tokugawa Shogun.

Although most Daigaku-besso (including Shogakuin) became merely titles, during Inseiki (the period of the cloister government), a title 'Junnain Shogakuin Ryoin Betto' (the principal of both Junnain and Shogakuin) was created along with the Junnain, the Goin (palace of the retired Emperor) of the retired Emperor Junna, as a post for successive Genji Choja (chiefs of the Minamoto clan), and this title later became one of the titles of samurai families, such as Ashikaga Shogun and Tokugawa Shogun.
